node.title: Mystery as Mammoth Tusk Discovered 10,000ft Below Pacific Ocean, Far From California Coast
node.description: The ancient tusk belongs to a Columbian mammoth, a species that became extinct about 10,000 years ago.

node.title: NASA Confirms Existence of Hundreds of New Worlds Outside Our Solar System
node.description: The space agency used a supercomputer program to confirm 301 suspected new planets, bringing the total to nearly 5,000.

node.title: Thousands of Low-Income Families to Get $1,800 Per Child Tax Credits Next Month
node.description: Low-income families who signed up for the credits before the deadline will get six months of the payments on December 15, the Internal Revenue Service said.

node.title: Federal government announces new commission for family, domestic and sexual violence prevention
node.description: A Domestic, Family and Sexual Violence Commission will be established by the Federal government to ensure "real and tangible" improvements are achieved under the next National Plan to end violence against women and children.

node.title: Malikah Shabazz, daughter of Malcolm X, found dead, NYPD says
node.description: Police say her death isn't considered suspicious at this point. She was 56.

node.title: Police say suspect intentionally plowed SUV into Wisconsin holiday parade
node.description: The suspect was being charged with five counts of first-degree intentional homicide. The five people killed at the parade ranged in age from 52 to 81.

node.title: Closing arguments in Ahmaud Arbery's killing focus on self-defense claims
node.description: Three White men are charged with murder for shooting a 25-year-old Black man who was jogging in the neighborhood.

node.title: Biden announces U.S. will release oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve
node.description: The administration has been pushing China, India, Japan and South Korea to join in a coordinated effort to release reserves of crude oil to help tamp down rising gasoline prices.

node.title: Prosecutors make final rebuttal in trial for Ahmaud Arbery's killing
node.description: The final rebuttal comes after both the prosecution and the defense delivered their closing arguments on Monday.

node.title: Clearview AI does well in another round of facial recognition accuracy tests.
node.description: This time, a federal agency assessed the ability to pick the right person out of millions of photos. Clearview’s app still faces legal hurdles.

node.title: President Biden will tap into U.S. oil reserves in concert with other nations.
node.description: To reduce global energy prices, the White House will release 50 million barrels of crude oil along with Britain, China, India, Japan and South Korea.

node.title: What We Know and Don’t Know About the Wisconsin Parade Attack
node.description: The suspect’s motivations are unclear in a tragedy that left five people dead and dozens more injured during a Christmas parade in Waukesha.

node.title: How Earth Might Be Saved if an Asteroid Was Headed Straight for Us
node.description: NASA's upcoming DART mission plans to hit an asteroid with a spacecraft to test Earth's defenses. But our chances of deflecting an asteroid depends on how much warning time we have.

node.title: You Can Now Get Paid $2,500 to Watch Your Favorite Christmas Movies
node.description: Reviews.org is looking for a Chief Holiday Cheermeister to simply review a selection of 25 holiday movies in 25 days for a generous sum of money.

node.title: RNC Paying Donald Trump's Legal Bills Reveals GOP Remains Hitched to Former President
node.description: The RNC called Trump "a leader of our party" and said that defending him was "critical to the GOP."

node.title: Members of "Dancing Grannies" among those killed in Wisconsin parade
node.description: The group said the members who died "were the glue" that "held us together."

node.title: ‘Boiling Point’ Review: The Worst Night in the Life of a Restaurant
node.description: Stephen Graham scowls and swears his way through a night of bad service in this single-shot drama set in London.

node.title: Hayao Miyazaki Prepares to Cast One Last Spell
node.description: No artist has explored the contradictions of humanity as sympathetically and critically as the Japanese animation legend. Now, at 80, he’s coming out of retirement with another movie.

node.title: Donald Trump Hosting $1K Per Person Mar-a-Lago Fundraiser for Florida Candidate
node.description: Anna Paulina Luna, who was endorsed by Trump in September, is currently leading in the polls in the race for Florida's 13th District.

node.title: AFL warns players they face 'trouble' over head knocks
node.description: Incoming AFL football operations boss Brad Scott vows not to introduce major changes next season, but will he seek to clear up rules around head contact?

node.title: Sri Lankan navy calls off search for missing people after ferry capsizes, killing at least six
node.description: Angry residents burned tyres and surrounded government offices, blaming officials for the the capsizing of a ferry that killed at least four children.

node.title: Dani Laidley returning to North Melbourne 'just being herself is a very, very positive sign'
node.description: Transgender advocates say Dani Laidley's return to Arden Street last week was an important step in recognising the trans community and showing how important a support network is in making people feel comfortable in their own skin.

node.title: Australia Might Genetically Modify Feral Cats Out of Existence
node.description: Report highlights the dire need to control its feral cat population and protect native wildlife.

node.title: Who is Chrystul Kizer? Black Woman's Case Under Spotlight After Kyle Rittenhouse Acquittal
node.description: Chrystul Kizer was 17 when she was charged in the killing of a man in Kenosha, Wisconsin, who was under investigation for child sex trafficking.

node.title: Parkland massacre families to get millions from DOJ over FBI inaction
node.description: Sixteen of 17 families of students killed settle lawsuit for $125 million-$130 million, sources say. The FBI didn't act on a tip saying Nikolas Cruz was going to shoot up a school.

node.title: The Latest Covid Surge
node.description: And how to make sense of it.

node.title: NASA probe set for historic asteroid deflection test
node.description: The $330 million DART probe will crash head-on into a small asteroid to test the possibility of averting future threats to Earth.

node.title: Senate Republicans hold fundraising edge over Democrats
node.description: But there is some good news for the Democratic Party —  its candidates have been outraising Republicans in key battleground races.

node.title: Watch Live As NASA Launches DART Mission to Smash Into Asteroid
node.description: The spacecraft will launch on Wednesday before hurtling into a space rock at 15,000 miles per hour in 2022 to test Earth's asteroid defences.

node.title: China's Peng Shuai Faces Uncertain Future Unless She Reverses Allegations
node.description: Uncertainty continues to surround the physical and psychological well-being of Chinese tennis star Peng Shuai as her #MeToo allegations are muted by Beijing.

node.title: 'Selling Sunset': How to Become A Real Estate Agent in Los Angeles
node.description: Netflix's "Selling Sunset" is set to return next month. If it makes you want to change career and sell luxury homes in California, here's how you can.

node.title: Alex Jones Says January 6 Committee 'Worse' Than McCarthyism Following Subpoena
node.description: The House select committee investigating the January 6 riot included the conspiracy theorist in a the latest round of subpoenas issued on Monday.

node.title: Venomous Snake Found Hiding Under Child's Bed Where Girl Was Sleeping
node.description: A video has shown the snake being captured after a family found it curled up under their daughter's bed.

node.title: Waukesha residents pack park for vigil for parade victims
node.description: "Our presence says that we, as a community, will work together to help all heal," Mayor Shawn Reilly said.

node.title: The Design Legacy of Covid? It’s All Around You.
node.description: Some objects and practices born in lockdown will probably stick around for decades — for better or worse.

node.title: How to Stand Correctly
node.description: Advice from the director of the Iyengar Yoga Institute of New York.

node.title: What Should I Do With My Big Fat Inheritance?
node.description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the burdens of philanthropy — and more.

node.title: How Alienation Became My Superpower
node.description: Feeling like an outsider can be painful. But it comes with secret gifts of perception.

node.title: A ‘Plant-Based’ Gift Guide
node.description: Twenty-seven ideas to satisfy tastes both garden variety and eccentric.

node.title: To Grandmother’s House, or Not. The Thanksgiving Travel Equation Is Tough to Solve.
node.description: The number of travelers this holiday weekend is expected to be close to prepandemic levels. But those numbers hide the kinds of decisions that families are making about how and where to gather. Here’s how six families are celebrating.

node.title: Why an NPR Quiz Show Panelist Loves Her ‘Messy Apartment’
node.description: Faith Salie, known for, among other things, her role on ‘Wait, Wait … Don’t Tell Me!,’ is ‘evangelical about the Upper West Side.’

node.title: ‘The Private Life of William Shakespeare’
node.description: James Shapiro reviews Lena Cowen Orlin’s book, which focuses on Shakespeare’s life in Stratford.

node.title: The San Francisco Homeless Crisis: What Has Gone Wrong?
node.description: Michael Shellenberger’s “San Fransicko” raises important questions about homelessness in San Francisco, but his answers are mired in controversy.

node.title: Warriors of History and Legend
node.description: Three new books examine the truths and myths surrounding the Spartans, the Vikings and the Spanish conquistadors.

node.title: Mystics, Monsters and the Macabre: Visual Books Honor the Occult
node.description: For anyone who believes in spirits unseen, three new titles on Voodoo dolls, tarot cards and flying witches.

node.title: New Political Thrillers Head to the Brink of Disaster (and Dive In)
node.description: “Never,” “Damascus Station” and “The Days to Come” imagine global crises and the spies and politicians trying to solve them.

node.title: Mario Vargas Llosa and the Age of the Strongman
node.description: His novel “Harsh Times” examines power and conspiracy at a crucial point in Latin American history.

node.title: 6 Podcasts About Unsolved Mysteries
node.description: A guide to navigating the explosion of shows delving into cold cases, unexplained disappearances and spooky events.

node.title: ‘West Side Story’ Star Ariana DeBose Is Always Ready for Her Next Role
node.description: After dancing in ‘Hamilton’ and playing Anita in Steven Spielberg’s new musical adaptation, the actress has her sights on a part entirely her own.

node.title: Here’s the Next Animal That Could Go Extinct
node.description: Only about 10 vaquitas remain, but scientists say there’s still hope for the elusive porpoises. Their fate largely depends on the Mexican government.

node.title: You Should Be Afraid of the Next ‘Lab Leak’
node.description: Covid might not have come out of a medical research lab, but it raises some urgent questions about how those facilities operate.

node.title: The Hubble Telescope Checks In With the Most Distant Planets
node.description: The spacecraft’s farseeing eye once again sets its gaze on Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune.

node.title: The Loss of a Child Takes a Physical Toll on the Heart
node.description: Grieving parents were at high risk of a heart attack in the days following the death of a child, and an increased risk may persist for years.

node.title: Vaping Is Risky. Why Is the F.D.A. Authorizing E-Cigarettes?
node.description: The agency has taken a controversial stand on vaping as a way to quit tobacco. This is what the research shows.

node.title: For Rules in Technology, the Challenge is to Balance Code and Law
node.description: Crypto fans have argued that code can be a better arbitrator than traditional regulators.

node.title: The Ronald Reagan Guide to Joe Biden’s Political Future
node.description: It is hard to act as an ambitious president without incurring a penalty, even if your policies are popular.

node.title: Why Is Murder Spiking? And Can Cities Address It Without Police?
node.description: What a progressive vision of public safety could look like.

node.title: Large Insurers Are Hatching a Plan to Take Down Coal
node.description: Thomas Buberl, the chief executive of the French insurance company AXA, wants the industry to stop covering mines and plants.

node.title: Can Synthetic Biology Save Us? This Scientist Thinks So.
node.description: Drew Endy is squarely focused on the potential of redesigning organisms for useful purposes. He also acknowledges significant challenges.

node.title: As We Live Longer, How Should Life Change? There Is a Blueprint.
node.description: “The New Map of Life” reimagines education, careers, cities and life transitions for lives that span a century (or more).

node.title: More Women Than Men Are Going to College. That May Change the Economy.
node.description: The rising gender gap in college education — currently three women for every two men — might turn out to be one of the most transformative trends of our time.

node.title: ‘Once We’re Gone, We’re Not Coming Back’
node.description: In Nebraska, a 151-year-old family farm struggles to survive.

node.title: As Virus Cases Rise in Europe, an Economic Toll Returns
node.description: A series of restrictions, including a lockdown in Austria, is expected to put a brake on economic growth.

node.title: Is the Four-Day Workweek Finally Within Our Grasp?
node.description: After embracing flexible work styles during the pandemic, some companies are now embracing a shorter week.

node.title: The Latest Farm Product: Carbon Credits
node.description: Global cropland has the potential to sequester as much as 570 million metric tons of carbon per year. New projects that pay farmers to adopt climate-friendly practices could help.

node.title: Jeffrey Epstein, in His Own Words
node.description: We obtained more than 2,000 pages of prison records, which contained vivid details about Epstein’s last days.

node.title: New York Moves to Allow 800,000 Noncitizens to Vote in Local Elections
node.description: New York City will become the largest municipality in the country to allow legal residents to vote if the legislation is approved as expected in December.

node.title: New York Targets Affluent Neighborhoods in Push for Affordable Housing
node.description: Supporters say the plans help address New York’s housing crisis and help integrate the city’s neighborhoods. Opponents see more gentrification and giveaways for developers.

node.title: Epstein’s Final Days: Celebrity Reminiscing and a Running Toilet
node.description: Newly released records show the disgraced financier living a mundane existence in jail before his suicide, while also spinning deceptions until the very end.

node.title: Enslaved to a Founding Father, She Sought Freedom in France
node.description: Brought from America to Paris by John Jay, an enslaved woman named Abigail died there trying to win her liberty as the statesman negotiated the freedom of the new nation.

node.title: Red Brands and Blue Brands: Is Hyper-Partisanship Coming for Corporate America?
node.description: Major brands and chief executives have become increasingly entangled in social and political debates. Is more to come?

node.title: Army Cadets Tried to Get Navy’s Goat, Again. Commanders Were Not Amused.
node.description: Rivalries among the nation’s military academies include a long history of mascot-stealing “spirit missions” before football games, despite official condemnations.

node.title: Pediatricians say Covid cases in children are on the rise.
node.description: Cases in children in the United States have risen by 32 percent from about two weeks ago, amid a rush to inoculate children ahead of the winter holiday season.

node.title: It’s Never Too Late to Pick Up Your Life and Move to Italy
node.description: Holly Herrmann vowed to move to Italy when she was 20. Her dream came true 38 years later.

node.title: What Is the Urban Dictionary Name Trend? How To Find Yours
node.description: Social media users are searching for quirky definitions of their own names in the Urban Dictionary. Here is how you can join in with the trend.

node.title: 'I Can't Afford a Big Frontal Attack on the President,' Mitch McConnell Confided
node.description: In this daily series, Newsweek explores the steps that led to the January 6 Capitol Riot.

node.title: Kyle Rittenhouse Says Lin Wood 'Disrespected My Wishes' by Keeping Him in Jail
node.description: The 18-year-old condemned his former attorneys during an interview with Tucker Carlson.

node.title: Cricket Australia names a five-person panel to decide on next men's Test captain
node.description: Cricket Australia will soon name its 47th men's Test captain, having finalised the five-person panel that will mull whether to elevate Pat Cummins.

node.title: Black Lives Matter Say They 'Don't F***' with Kyle Rittenhouse
node.description: Rittenhouse said he supports the Black Lives Matter movement in his first television interview since his acquittal.

node.title: U.S. Navy Destroyer Sails Through Taiwan Strait Week After Biden-Xi Summit
node.description: USS Milius' maiden voyage through the international waters of the Taiwan Strait was also the U.S. Navy's 11th such operation of the year.

node.title: Kolohe the Hawaiian Monk Seal Dies from Parasitic Disease after Ingesting Fishing Gear
node.description: The adult monk seal was suffering from toxoplasmosis and had become malnourished after swallowing multiple hooks and a fishing line.

node.title: Paralyzed Cheerleader Makayla Noble Brushes Teeth Herself at Home for First Time Since Accident
node.description: The Texas teenager suffered a spinal cord injury in September while training, and was hospitalized for around two months.

node.title: Federal Health Minister confirms domestic travellers don't have to pay for COVID-19 tests
node.description: The Federal Health Minister Greg Hunt has confirmed domestic travellers do not have to pay for COVID-19 tests, which state and territories require for entry, if they're obtained at a state-run clinic.

node.title: Queenstown businesses grappling with staff shortages ahead of summer
node.description: Queenstown businesses are grappling with severe staff shortages, with some managers preparing to pitch in on the front line this summer.

node.title: Tourists Dribble in Again
node.description: With U.S. borders open again, “I ♥ Tourists” is the mantra for restaurateurs and hotel operators. But some do not expect a  rebound until next year.

node.title: Ash Barty announces engagement
node.description: Australian world number one tennis player Ash Barty has announced her engagement to her partner of four years, Garry Kissick.

node.title: Fire guts bus carrying young people in Bulgaria, killing at least 45
node.description: The cause of the blaze remained unclear, but no other vehicles were involved in the incident.

node.title: End could be in sight for Kawerau's landbanked derelict houses
node.description: Kawerau Mayor Malcolm Campbell says the government allowing landbanked houses to become derelict when so many people are homeless is a travesty.

node.title: Families of children massacred in Parkland shooting paid millions over FBI inaction
node.description: Families of those killed and wounded in the 2018 Florida high school massacre say they have reached a multi-million dollar settlement with the US government over the FBI's failure to act on a confidential tip.

node.title: Officers warns of more deaths on popular Mt Augustus climbing trail if paths not closed in hot months
node.description: An inquest into the deaths of four hikers on Western Australia's remote Mount Augustus is told a police officer believes the summit trail should be closed during the hottest half of the year.

node.title: Invercargill City Council votes to phase out independent oversight
node.description: The Invercargill City Council has voted to start phasing out independent oversight of its governance from next month following a turbulent period.

node.title: Traffic light system: Opposition says govt communication confusing
node.description: Ten days out from the new traffic light system, many businesses still feel in the dark and opposition parties are calling for clarity.

node.title: Auckland hairdressers doing 'all they can' to prepare for vaccine passes
node.description: Auckland hairdressers are preparing for a surge in customers when they are allowed to re-open on Friday, a week before businesses adjust to new requirements.

node.title: Late Night Celebrates Biden’s 79th Birthday
node.description: Jimmy Fallon joked that when the president blew out his candles, “everyone started clapping and the lights went on and off.”

node.title: Why China Can’t Bury Peng Shuai and Its #MeToo Scandal
node.description: Accustomed to forcing messages on audiences at home and abroad, its propaganda machine hasn’t learned how to craft a narrative that stands up to scrutiny.

node.title: Mark McGowan considers moving family from home in Perth's south amid alleged threats
node.description: WA Premier Mark McGowan is considering temporarily moving his family out of their Rockingham home after threats were allegedly made against him and his wife and children.

node.title: Cambridge's St Peter's School reveals details of child sexual abuse, apologises to former students
node.description: St Peter's School in Cambridge has revealed details of child sexual abuse at the college and apologised to former students for cases stretching back decades. Audio

node.title: New Zealand Breakers camp hit by Covid-19
node.description: The New Zealand Breakers are self-isolating in Melbourne after four members of their touring party test positive for Covid-19.

node.title: Australians who make 'statements of belief' protected under watered-down religious discrimination bill
node.description: The details of a long-awaited and highly contentious bill to strengthen protections for religious beliefs are revealed, including safeguards for organisations that want workers to practise their religion.

node.title: ANZ suspends low-deposit home loans to comply with RBNZ rules
node.description: The ANZ bank has put a clamp on low-deposit lending to owner-occupiers wanting to buy existing homes as it moves to comply with tighter Reserve Bank lending rules.
